note.p: Cox Macro, privately owned, anonymous. French, first half of the 14th century.
Parchment, 295 x 220 mm, 163 folios.

Parchment has minor soiling due to use. A few worm holes in first 4 and final 8 fols. Fol. 155r missing and replaced with a later piece of parchment (note later script that attempts to approximate the hand of the Rose text and the ruling that is clearly not original).

list.head: Collation:
list.item: 89-96(note modern foliation gets off in this gathering)
153-154imperfect, two stubs remaining; formerly a quire containing four leaves

note.p: Bound mostly in quarternios, with exceptions noted above. Fols 67-74 and 75-80 are bound out of order; notations at the bottoms of 66v (Vte usque ad octa folio) and 74v (Vte usque ad vi folia) instruct the reader to jump ahead eight and six folios respectively in order to read the text in the correct order. The hand responsible for these instructions is early, suggesting that the folios were misbound early in the history of the codex. No quire marks or signatures. Catchwords on 32v and 40v only. Modern foliation on lower right of rectos in pencil skips folio 92, after which count is off by one (Bond and Faye report 162 folios due to incorrect modern foliation).

Ruled in brown ink. A few holes from prickings survive in inner margin and along bottom. Ruled in two columns. Eight vertical and two horizontal through lines. Each column is delineated by a through line on either side and contains two additional through lines, one forming a compartment for the first letter of each line, and the second an empty compartment to separate that letter from the rest of the line. One horizontal line each at top and bottom of text block. Text block 205 x 143 mm. 36 lines per column.

The manuscript is the work of two scribes; one completes up through fol. 27v and the second finishes the manuscript. Written in textualis throughout. Corrections, including lining through, erasure, and the use of marginal notation to indicate lines out of order, distributed sparsely throughout, some in a different hand.

No rubrication or highlighting other than initials. Foliate initial begins Roman de la Rose - pinkish M with white tracery, 33 x 40 mm - tendrils with leaves and topped by animal heads are within legs of letter. Blue background with white tracery. Littera duplex initials with penwork throughout, alternating blue letter with red penwork and red letter with blue penwork. Historiated initial U at beginning of La Chastelaine de Vergi, 44 x 42 mm; the U contains an image with a tree in the center. On the left stands the lover, on the right a woman standing in a doorway. A small white dogs runs across the bottom, heading towards the lover. Lover dressed in blue robe, woman in orange and blue. Red background within letter. Pinkish letter with white tracery set on blue background with white tracery. Tendril extends into upper margin. No line fillers or borders.

One miniature at the beginning of Roman de la Rose, 52 x 66 mm, features the poet asleep in bed with Dangier at foot of bed holding club. A tree stands at center in background. Blue bed clothes, brownish-red robe on Dangier, red flowers on tree, red frame with white tracery. Orange background. A number of blank areas ranging in size from 4-6 lines early in the manuscript may have been left for other decoration, or may have been rubrics or other features in the exemplar that were abandoned after some time by the copyist (e.g top of 12r, top of 12v, 14r, 14v, 15r).

Five raised bands on spine. Red morocco. Gold pattern on spine; gilt ownership stamp of Hudson Gurney on front and back covers, center. Paper flyleaves and end papers. Fol. 163 glued to paper flyleaf on verso side.
